Lucienne est âgée de 31 ans et est mariée à un certain Yaya. Lucienne est mère de trois enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés et tous sont à la charge du couple. Lucienne a peu fréquenté l’école, mais a appris la coiffure, activité qu'elle exerce dans son quartier. Parallèlement à cette activité, Lucienne vend des mèches et des boissons. Cette activité lui permet de répondre sans grande difficulté à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Lucienne s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Lucienne sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe TOUT EST GRÂCE 20, un crédit auprès de ALIDé.

loans.use: Acheter des articles de coiffure et des boissons.

loans.name: Zoila

texts.es: Doña Zoila, es una mujer de 55 años de edad, ama de casa y agricultora, casada y madre de cinco hijos pero solo uno vive aún en su casa quien colabora ayudando a su padre a realizar tareas en el campo. Ella tiene un grado de educación primaria cursado hasta el 3 grado ya que sus padres de escasos recursos no pudieron apoyarle y darle la oportunidad de convertirse en profesional. Desde muy temprana edad se dedicó a la siembra y cultivo de café aprendiendo de su padre las técnicas necesarias para sembrar, fortalecer, cultivar y cortar el grano para posteriormente lavarlo secarlo y despulparlo para posteriormente venderlo a los compradores que llegan de todos los alrededores de la zona. El terreno que ella y su esposo trabaja fue obtenido gracias al esfuerzo que han realizado por muchos años. Sus sueños son poder ampliar sus cultivos de café mediante la compra de más tierra y generar mayores ingresos para su familia y hogar. Doña Zoila solicita crédito a la cooperativa COMIXMUL para la compra de insumos agrícolas y poder invertir y asistir en sus cultivos de café, mismos que ayudan al final de cada temporada al fortalecimiento económico de la familia.
texts.en:
Zoila is a 55-year-old woman.  She is a housewife and a farmer.  She is married and is the mother of five children, although only one of them still lives at home.  That one helps out in the fields.  Zoila has a primary education, having only gone to school through the third grade because with scarce resources, her parents couldn't support her and give her the opportunity to become a professional.  

From a very young age she has worked sowing and growing coffee plants.  She learned the necessary techniques from her father to sow, strengthen, cultivate, and then cut the beans to later wash, dry, and pulp them.  These are later sold to buyers who come from all around the area.  

The land that she and her husband work was obtained thanks to the efforts they have made over the years.  Their dreams are to be able to increase their coffee plantings by purchasing more land and to generate greater earnings for their family and home.  Zoila is asking for this loan from COMIXMUL for the purchase of farming supplies, to be able to invest in and take care of her coffee plants; this will help the financial strength of her family at the end of each season.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, soil amendments, and foliar treatments, and to take care of her coffee plants.

loans.name: Adella

texts.en:
Adella aged 48 years. She is married with 3 children aged between 12 and 20 years. They all go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing maize for the past 30 years. While her husband is a business man. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to buy a goat. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Aiming to get ahead and improve himself that’s the ultimate goal for Stephen. Stephen resides in Chepmet, a remote village in the lush hills of Nandihills, in the Rift Valley of Kenya. As the key breadwinner of his family he has been practicing mixed farming for the past 11 years. Because of the immense knowledge he has of farming, he commands a lot of respect from other farmers in his village. His primary sources of income have been milk, eggs, and crops. Although he has been making profits from farming, he has identified a “niche market” for selling cereals; the only big challenge he faces is lack of funds. 

He is requesting a loan to buy cereals. He intends to buy different varieties of cereals; that is, maize, sorghum, rice, wheat, barley, and millet, to sell in the local market. Market for the cereals is never a problem because the demand is always high, and he plans to take advantage of that. 

Because of the good relationship he has with his neighbors, he plans to increase his market by using word of mouth to reach more customers and markets. He plans that, through accumulated profits, he will be able to buy a milling machine for grinding maize. Through this loan, Stephen’s life will take another turn, and he will be able to secure the future of his family. You can help this man achieve his dreams with this loan, which will surely bring big profits.
With your support of this loan, you will be promoting the farming ideas of a Kenyan!

loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For purchasing a piece of land

loans.name: Jose Martin

texts.en:
Hello my name is Jose Martin and I work primarily as a merchant, I have had a grocery store in my own home for several years now, which creates enough income to cover family expenses and other necessities. Thanks to this business I have given an education to my children and bettered my standard of living.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor

Hola mi nombre el Jose Martin, mi actividad principal comercio, cuento con una pulperia en mi casa de habitación desde hace varios años, la que me genera ingresos para cubrir los gastos familiares y otros compromisos con proveedores, gracias sa este negocio e dado educacion a mis hijos y he logrado mejorar mi vivienda.

loans.use: To purchase rice, butter, beans, dairy goods, sausages, refreshments, oil, toilet paper, and other items.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Lucy would like to buy a pig

loans.name: Murtazo

texts.en: Murtazo is a 30 year old young man. He is married (his wife is on the photo) and he has 3 small children. He has no constant work, which is why he decided to trade goods. He has chosen food products and cooling drinks. His shop is located on a car route, which links the district centre where he lives, Lohuti and the regional centre, Khujand. Trade here is very active and almost every day he goes to buy goods. In March of this year, he decided to take a loan in Microinvest to renew his small shop. Now he wants to get $1200 for 12 months to purchase cooling drinks, as some increase is possible in their price.

loans.use: To purchase cooling drinks

loans.name: Maribel

texts.es:
Maribel is married and the mother of three children, two sons, 6 and 14, and one daughter, 11. Her husband's small income is not enough to cover the needs of the family so Maribel, an entrepeneurial woman, decided to start her own business selling ice cream a year ago. Summer temperatures in Monclova (a city in the northern Mexican state of Coahuila) are very high and, seeing the demand for her ice cream increase, Maribel responded by adding new flavors and offering ice cream in cones.

Maribel now needs a $125 loan that she will use to buy merchandise so that she can increase her sales. She promises to repay that amount in 3 months. With your help, this family can improve their lives. Decide to help. Thank you.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer.

Maribel es casada y tiene dos hijos, de 6 y 14 años de edad y una hija de 11. Su esposo recibe un salario muy bajo, insuficiente para cubrir las necesidades de su familia, pero como Maribel es una mujer emprendedora decidió comenzar su propio negocio con la venta de helados hace un año, vio en este negocio una muy buena oportunidad ya que en verano las temperaturas en Monclova, Coahuila son muy altas y la demanda por estos productos se incrementa, comenzó a vender solo paletas heladas y a petición de sus clientes fue incorporando otros tipos de helados y conos.

En estos momentos Maribel necesita un préstamo de $ 125 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía para poder incrementar sus ventas, ella promete devolver esta cantidad en 3 meses. Con tu ayuda esta familia puede mejorar sus condiciones de vida, decídete a apoyarlos, muchas gracias.

loans.use: Buy merchandise.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Mrs. Florence Osagile sells kerosene. She is married with 5 children and is 41 years old and lives in Benin City. She is in need of $1175 to buy more kerosene for sale. She has been a faithful client and leader of her union and  has been in this business since 1996.

loans.use: To buy more kerosene for sale

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Mrs. Halima M. runs a colourful fruit and vegetable stall in the colourful market town of Kigogo, Tanzania. Halima is married with three children, aged 6 months, 4 and 14. She is requesting a loan of TSH 300,000 to buy more produce to expand her business, including the delicious in-season fruits available here, such as mangoes, bananas, pawpaw, watermelon and pineapple.

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called "sale and leaseback" arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additonal fruit and vegetables for her market stall.

loans.name: Hin

texts.en:
Miss Hin S., 26, is single and lives with her two little sisters and one brother and her grandmother in Preyveng province, Cambodia. To support her entire family, she works as a broker buying food from her area and reselling it in Phnom Penh city earning about US$ 25/day in revenue.Two of her sisters are currently employed at a garment factory and her little brother is a student.

Miss Hin S. has humbly requested a loan to purchase more foodstuffs to meet her customers’ needs and otherwise to invest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more food to meet her customers’ needs and otherwise invest in her business

loans.name: Run

texts.en: Mrs. Run P., age 31, works selling various kinds of fruits at Phsar Suong market in Kampong Cham, making on average around $2.40 each day in revenue. Her husband is a blacksmith making around $6 per day in revenue. Her two children are too young to attend school. She would like to request this loan of $1000 in order to expand her inventory of fruit to meet her clients’ needs. The remainder of the loan is to buy blacksmith’s tools to facilitate her husband’s work.

loans.use: Run would like to purchase fruit and blacksmith tools.

loans.name: Kitimbwa Mixed Group

texts.en:
Rose N., age 34, is the chairperson of Kitimbwa Mixed group. She is married with seven children and also looks after two kids that belong to her siblings. She has a retail shop in Kitimbwa, a trading center outside of Kayunga town. She usually buys goods from the wholesale shops in Kayunga and sells them in her shop, and so far her shop is prospering.

A previous loan enabled Rose to do more than just pay her children’s school fees and pay her rent. In addition, she has expanded her business to include farming; with the help of her husband, she runs a coffee and maize plantation. With this loan, she plans to restock her shop by buying sugar, soap, salt, and petroleum jelly. She hopes that this will increase her profits.

loans.use: To buy sugar, soap, salt, and petroleum jelly for her shop

loans.name: Lucia's Group

texts.es:
This is a new committee full of expectations, with a desire to grow. The group arose after one of the members of the group, Paola C., had knowledge of the "committee of enterprising women" program that the Paraguayan Foundation is developing.

She was part of another group for a time, but, upon that group being dissolved, she sought to form a new group. So she contacted neighbors and friends to hold a meeting where one of the credit officers of the Foundation could explain to them better the purpose of the program.

Thus the new committee arose that now requests a loan to invest in their different activities. These enterprising and dynamic women carry out different types of activities that help to generate income for their families. Among these diverse activities we can cite: recycling, sale of clothes, lingerie, fast food, products for the home, etc.

Each one will receive a part of the loan and will work together to make their payments in a punctual manner. In this way when they pay off their first loan, the foundation will be able to agree to a larger loan.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Este es un comité nuevo, lleno de expectativas, con ganas de crecer. El grupo surgió luego de que una de las integrantes del grupo, Paola C., tuvo conocimiento del programa “comité de mujeres emprendedoras” que desarrolla la Fundación Paraguaya.

Ella formo parte de otro grupo durante un tiempo, pero al disolverse este, ella busco formar un nuevo grupo, fue así que contacto a vecinas y amigas para realizar una reunión donde uno de los oficiales de créditos de la Fundación pudo explicarles mejor la finalidad del programa.

Así surge el nuevo comité que hoy día solicita el crédito para invertirlos en sus diferentes actividades. Estas mujeres emprendedoras y dinámicas realizan distintos tipos de actividades que les ayuda a generar ingresos para sus familias; entre estas diversas actividades podemos citar: reciclaje, ventas de ropas, lencerías, comidas rápidas, productos para el hogar, etc.

Cada una recibirá una parte del crédito y se comprometerá a pagar de forma puntual sus cuotas, así de este modo cuando concluyan su primer ciclo podrán acceder a un crédito superior.

loans.use: To buy clothes such as T-shirts, pants, shirts, and footwear; ingredients for foods like: vegetables, meat, sugar, fruits; and to purchase supplies for recycling.

loans.name: Rosa Consuelo

texts.en:
Rosa Consuelo R. G. has a business selling bulk sugar, rice, and wheat.  Her business is located in Salpo, a village high in the Sierras of La Libertad Region.  She’s had her business for two years and has patiently acquired a group of loyal customers.

Rosa is 42-years old, married, and has 5 children.  She is happy to have her business and help her family.  Rosa looks forward to growing her business and giving her children more opportunities in life than she had.

A member of the community bank Virgen de Las Mercedes, Rosa is requesting a loan of $375 to repay over 6 months.  She will use the loan to restock her business with sugar, wheat, and corn.

loans.use: To restock business with sugar, wheat, and corn.

loans.name: Zulfiya.

texts.ru:
Zulfiya U. lives in the city of Vahdat. She is 58 years old, married, and has 6 children. She completed secondary education. Zulfiya has raised animals since she was young. Currently the family has one dairy cow with a calf, but still not enough dairy products for the family. Buying an additional cow isn’t possible with the family’s tight financial situation, and at the market milk is expensive. Yet the small children in her family need these dairy products. After talking with her family, Zulfiya decided to take out a loan to buy a dairy cow. The loan will be repaid in 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer.

Умарова Зульфия жительница города Вахдат. Возраст 58 лет,замужем , имеет 6 детей. Образование среднее. Клиентка с молодости занимается животноводством. В данный момент ее семья имеет одну дойную корову с теленком.Но кисло-молочной продукции ее семье не хватает.А покупать дополнительно ее семье не позволяет финансовое положение.На рынке молоко стоит дорого.А в семье клиентки есть маленькие дети ,которым необходимы эти продукты. Посоветовавшись с семьей Зульфия решила взять кредит для покупки дойной коровы.Планирует погасить кредит в течении 10 месяцев

loans.use: Purchase of a dairy cow

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita has sold food for 5 years. She learned this business through her mother, who also was dedicated to this activity.

Every evening, starting at 5:30, she puts out tables and chairs on the patio outside her house and sells food until and after 10:00 at night.

Margarita used to work in a shoe store, but she had to stop this work because she had her first daughter. For her, the business of selling food is favorable, because she can stay home with her children.

The loans that she has received have served her to increase her capital and to invest in the purchase of ingredients that she needs to make her food.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Margarita vende comida desde hace 5 años. Ella conoció el negocio a raíz de su mamá, quien también se ha dedicado a esta actividad.

Todas las tardes, a partir de las 5.30, ella saca mesas y sillas al patio exterior de su casa, y vende comida hasta pasada las 10 de la noche.

Margarita antes trabajaba en un taller de zapatillas, pero tuvo que dejar este trabajo debido a que tuvo su primera hija. Para ella, el negocio de venta de comida le resulta propicio, ya que puede quedarse en casa con sus hijos.

Los préstamos que ha recibido le han servido para incrementar su capital e invertir en la compra de ingredientes que necesita para sus comidas.

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of ingredients that she needs to make her food

loans.name: Sabougnouman (Le Porte Bonheur Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Sabougnouman group are on average 35 and have an average of 4 children. They live in polygamous households with their husbands, co-spouses, and children in the Ouassila Wèrè neighborhood of the village of Ouassila, Ségou Prefecture (Republic of Mali). These women are linked by professional ties, by kinship, by friendship and by being neighbors. They essentially sell condiments, cereals, fresh cow’s milk, and firewood. These businesses often function daily (milk sales) or spread out over time (sales of cereals, wood, and condiments).

In order to satisfy the ever increasing demands of their clientele, they decided to join the credit program of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso which agreed to grant them their first group loan. The women of the group often do their procurement of goods directly in Ouassila (dried grains and fresh cow’s milk), sometimes in surrounding villages (such as Konodimini in the case of firewood) and the regional capital Ségou (for condiments and rice).

With this loan they intend to buy350 liters of fresh cow’s milk, 300 kg of dried cereals and legumes (millet, beans, peanuts, etc.), 4 wagon loads of firewood and 285 kg of condiments and of rice.

Their sales are generally retail, for cash or on credit, on market days, in the village square, and out of their homes (night and day). The clientele generally consists of women and men who come from other villages to make their purchases in Ouassila. The group members expect to make a monthly profit of 10,000 FCFA (about US$ 25).

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Sabougnouman ont en moyenne 35 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des foyers polygames avec leurs maris coépouses et enfants dans le quartier Ouassila Wèrè du village de Ouassila préfecture de Ségou (république du Mali.) Ces femmes sont liées par des relations professionnelles, de parenté, d’amitié et de voisinage. Elles font essentiellement le commerce de condiments alimentaires, de céréales, de lait frais de vache et du bois de chauffe. Les activités menées sont souvent quotidiennes (le lait) ou étalées dans le temps (les céréales, le bois et les condiments).

Afin de satisfaire une demande de plus en plus croissante de la clientèle, elles décidèrent d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso qui accepta de leurs accorder leur premier prêt. Les femmes de groupe se ravitaillent souvent sur place à Ouassila (en céréales sèches et lait frais de vache), parfois dans les villages environnants (tel Konodimini en bois de chauffe) et dans la capitale régionale Ségou (en condiments alimentaires et en riz).

Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt : 350 litres de lait frais de vache (vente quotidienne), 300 kg de céréales sèches (mil haricot arachide etc.) 4 chargements de charrette en bois de chauffe et 285 kg de condiments et de riz.

Les ventes sont effectuées généralement en détail, au comptant et à crédit les jours de foires, sur la place publique du village et à domicile (nuit et jour). La clientèle généralement constituée de femmes et d’hommes se déplace des autres villages pour venir faire des achats à Ouassila. Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 10.000FCFA.

loans.use:
Purchase of milk, cereals, firewood, and condiments for re-sale

Achat de lait, de céréales, de bois de chauffe et de condiments

loans.name: Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.es:
As the chance of securing capital to start a small enterprise seemed slim, one day these ladies decided to take part in a women’s committee program at the Fundación Paraguaya, which unites women with limited resources and gives them a small amount of credit so that they are able to develop.

The women who belong to this committee take part in various activities, such as purchase and sale of merchandise from home or purchasing consumables to make dishes which is what the women who sell food do. Also, there are women who sort and sell disused materials such as cardboard, plastics and metals, and women who make and sell cleaning products.

As there are so many restrictions in place for their children, academically as well as economically, these women work twice as hard to generate more family income and give their children the opportunity to study and gain a good job one day.

Translated from Spanish by Lucy Williams, Kiva volunteer

Debido a que sus posibilidades de conseguir capital para empezar un pequeño emprendimiento se veía muy dificultoso, ellas decidieron un día participar del programa comité de mujeres de la Fundación Paraguaya, que agrupa a mujeres de escasos recursos y les provee de un pequeño crédito para impulsar su deseo de progreso.

Las señoras pertenecientes a este comité se dedican a diversas actividades, entre las que podemos citar la compra y venta de mercaderías en algunos casos o compra de insumos para la elaboración de comidas que es el caso de las señoras que se dedican a la venta de comestibles. También hay señoras que realizan clasificación y venta de materiales en desuso como cartón, plásticos, y metales, y señoras que se dedican a la fabricación y venta de productos de limpieza.

Para que sus hijos no pasen por las mismas limitaciones tanto económicas como académicas se esfuerzan el doble para generar mas ingresos a sus familias y poder brindarles posibilidades de estudiar y optar por un buen empleo.

loans.use: To buy oranges, bananas, pineapple, melon, watermelon and apple to sell on. To buy cosmetics, beer, drinks. To buy fabric to make sheets, tablecloths and clothes.

loans.name: Baloglan

texts.en:
Baloglan E. is a 32-year-old trader who sells cosmetics such as shampoo, perfume, lacquer and more. He is married and has one daughter. He does not have a permanent job because it is very hard to find any employment in the region he is living in. 

He started his business in 1996 when he understood that he could never find a job and the only way to cover family needs is to start his own business. He took this chance and it worked. Baloglan lives with his old parents and his store brings him income that is just enough to cover basic family needs. He would like to improve their life and for this purpose he applied for a 1200 USD loan. He will use this loan to purchase more inventory for his store and increase his income.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana B. is a single parent with one child. She has received schooling through the Junior High level. Since 2003, Julianer has sold baby clothing at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast. Juliana uses her income to pay for the family's financial needs and to care for her child. Juliana will use the loan to purchase baby clothing to meet the increase in demand because the stock she is able to purchase with her capital is not enough to meet this demand She is, therefore, asking for a loan that will enable her to buy more baby clothing. With the new profits from her expanded business, Juliana plans to reinvest into her business to increase her income.

loans.use: To buy baby clothing

loans.name: Mai Thi

texts.vi: Chị T. tham  gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2005. Vòng vốn đầu tiên chị vay  3.000.000đ để đầu tư vào buôn bán thịt lợn. Hiện nay ngoài buôn bán thịt lợn gia đình chị còn đầu tư vốn để mua máy móc phục vụ cho nhu cầu khoan cắt bê tông của người dân địa phương.Với mức T. nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng, việc hoàn trả vốn của gia định chị T. rất T.ận lợi. Vì thế vòng vốn tới chị xin vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm máy móc phục vụ cho dịch vụ khoan cắt bê tông của gia đình
texts.en:
T. participates in TYM fund since 2005. Her first loan, 3.000.000 VND, was used to start a business selling pork. Today, beside selling pork, she and her family also invested their money in a concrete cutting machine to offer their service to cut concrete. Their income is 4.000.000 VND a month so they won't have trouble making the loan payment. This time she is requesting a loan of 9.000.000 VND to buy invest and buy more machinery to better serve their customers.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy machinery

loans.name: Tom

texts.en: Mrs. Tom K., age 49, is a single woman, and a resident in Ptasrong Commune in the Pursat Province. She earns her income from growing rice and selling a small amount of groceries from her home. She lives with her two nephews, both of whom help her with the farm work. Tom works very hard trying to grow her business. To earn extra a revenue, Tom is requesting a loan so that she can purchase piglets for breeding.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to breed.

loans.name: Emilio

texts.es:
Emilio tiene un taller de  carpintería donde elabora muebles  y también hace arreglo de muebles.
Su vivienda y taller se encuentran ubicados en la zona de Alto de Villa San Antonio de la Ciudad de La Paz.
El crédito será destinado para la compra de materia prima (madera, venesta, cola y clavos)
Es la sexta ve que solicita un crédito en Impro, su historial lo califica como cliente 1 es decir con buen cumplimiento en el pago de su crédito.
Emilio es una persona muy responsable y así lo ha demostrado durante  estos años. Es cliente de IMPRO desde el año 2004.
texts.en:
Emilio has a carpenter's shop where he makes furniture and also repairs furniture.

His home and his shop are located in the region of Alto de Villa San antonio in the city of La Paz.

This loan will be used to purchase materials (wood, plywood, glue and nails).

This is the sixth time he is requesting a loan through Impro (Kiva Field Partner). His credit hisotry qualifies him as a Client 1, which means that he has made his payments on time.

Emilio is a very responsible person, as he has demonstrated these past years. He has been a client of Impro (Kiva Field Partner) since the year 2004.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase wood, plywood, glue and nails for his carpentry business.

loans.name: Diana Aimee

texts.es:
Diana Aimee R. vive en el municipio de Soyapango en el departamento de San Salvador.
El ánimo y espíritu para superarse lo recibe diariamente en los ojos de su hijita Marcela, de tan solo ocho años de edad. Marcela cursa el cuarto grado y recién empieza a aprender aritmética.
Diana Aimee ha luchado por años dándole a Marcela una vida  digna, abriendo un pequeño negocio de artesanías en el mercado de Soyapango, donde vende artículos de barro y decoración ornamental. Con este puesto de artesanías, Diana Aimee ha logrado costearse  educación superior, y está cerca de graduarse en contaduría pública en la Universidad Don Bosco.
Diana solicita un préstamo para reinvertir en su negocio y cubrir sus múltiples gastos, y a la vez, le permita graduarse de la universidad y convertirse en el ejemplo que su hijita merece.
texts.en:
Diana Aimee R. lives in San Salvador area in the municipality of Soyapango. Everyday, she finds the courage and spirit to improve her life when she looks into the eyes of her young daughter, Marcela, who is only eight years old. Marcela is in the fourth grade and she just started learning arithmetic. Diana Aimee has fought for years to give Marcela a good life, by opening a small handicrafts business in the Soyapango market, where she sells clay products and ornamental decorations. With this handicrafts business, Diana Aimee has been able to pay the costs of her higher education and is about to graduate with a degree in public accounting from the Don Bosco University. Diana is requesting a loan to reinvest in her business and cover her various expenses and, at the same time, allow her to graduate from the university and become the example her little daughter deserves.

Translated from Spanish by Tara Binetti, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clay handicrafts

loans.name: Amanalah Group

texts.en:
Amanalah is the group leader of the Amanalah group. There are five members in this group and they all live in district 17 in Kabul Afghanistan. The total amount that the group members want to take is 50000 Afghani for the term of 7 months. Each member wants to take the loan to help the progress of his/her business. Aqalah wants to take a loan for purchasing materials for her brother's tailoring business. Anefa wants to take a loan for her brother’s beading business. bobo gull wants to take a loan for her brother’s quilt business. M. Rafe wants to take a loan for his fruit cart business. Amanalah wants to take a loan for his work shop.  
They all want to say that with these loans they will be able to progress in their businesses.

loans.use: They want to buy the necessary materials for they businesses

loans.name: Elizerbeth

texts.en: Elizberth P. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and onions and is requesting a loan to expand her business.  Elizberth is 50 years old and is married. Her husband is a peasant . She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop. BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and provides legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as is measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open up a shop

loans.name: Davaadorj

texts.en:
Davaadorj S. is the widowed mother of two children. She lives in Arhanghay province, one of Mongolia's central provinces, with her son and grandson. Her son is a lawyer by training, but now works for his mother's business.

Since 2004, Davaadorj has been running a small souvenir shop in the local history museum. The items she sells are bought by her son wholesale in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. When she began to run her retail business, her working capital was 300,000 tugrug. As a result of her doing well, the capital has increased to 400,000 MNT.

Davaadorj requests a loan to purchase more "Made in Mongolia" souvenirs to increase her inventory as the tourism season approaches.

loans.use: To purchase more "Made in Mongolia" souvenirs

loans.name: Alhaji

texts.en: Alhaji A. is 45 years old and married with six children. He prints calendars, stickers, invitation cards, etc. He is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more printing materials. He says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more printing materials

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria has been a bean seller in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for 5 years. She belongs to the Namba tatu east group.  She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $125. Every day she works at her business for 9 hours.  

She is requesting her third loan through BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more beans to add her current stock, to expand her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business.

Maria is 32 years old, married, and has two children: ages 10 and 7. She also cares for two additional dependents.

loans.use: To buy more beans to add her current stock, to expand her business

loans.name: Ludivina

texts.en:
Ludivina is 35 years old and has a stand where she sells sim cards and minutes for two local cell phone companies. Ludivina has been running this stand for three years and it has been a big help to her family, especially for the education of her three children in school.

Ludivina is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000 as working capital for her business and to help repair her husband’s motorcycle transport.

loans.use: To use as working capital for her business and to repair her husband’s motorcycle transport

loans.name: Zubaida Benedito

texts.pt:
Zubaida Benedito V. de 22 anos nasceu no distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, estudou até décima primeira classe e teve de interromper devido as dificuldades financeiras da família. Casada maritalmente e mãe de um filho de dois anos. 

Zubaida nunca viveu fora de Boane, distrito onde nasceu, mas teve de deixar de viver com os pais quando ficou grávida, passando a viver com o marido, mas como havia aprendido o tratamento de cabelo junto com o marido juntaram algum dinheiro para investimentos de salão de cabeleireiro.

A receita diária varia entre 1,500.00MT – 2,500.00MT, ela trabalha das 8:00 – 18:00hrs e presta de serviços de tratamento de cabelos, pedicure, manicure, entre outros.

Com o empréstimo de 11,000.00MT, pretende comprar produtos diversos para garantir que as clientes encontrem todas as soluções para sua beleza.

No futuro pensa juntar algum dinheiro para adquirir um meio de transporte familiar.
texts.en:
Zubaida Benedito V. is 22 years old and was born in the Boane district of Maputo Province. She studied until tenth grade and had to interrupt her studies on account of her family's financial difficulties. She is married and the mother of a two-year-old child.

Zubaida has never lived outside of Boane, the district where she was born. She moved out of her parents' place and moved in with her husband when she became pregnant. As she and her husband had learned hairdressing together, they put together some money to invest in a hair salon.

Her daily income varies between 1,500 MT (meticais) and 2,500 MT. She works from 8:00am to 6:00pm and provides hair services, pedicures, and manicures, among other services.

With the loan of 11,000 MT, she plans to buy a diversity of products to make sure that her clients find the solutions for all their beauty needs at her salon.

In the future she is planning to put some money together to acquire trasportation for her family.

Translated from Portuguese by April Newman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase variety and stock at her beauty salon

loans.name: Nguyên Thị
loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en:
Beverly A. is from the village of Barandiaz, Pangantucan Bukidnon. She is 54 years old. Beverly is married and has 10 adult children. To make a living, Beverly owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Beverly has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Beverly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Beverly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Beverly is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Beverly from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Marilee

texts.en:
Marilee is requesting a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders to further support her parents in their medical and basic necessities. She is still single at the age of 24 and she is presently living in her parents' house located in Barangay Madiangat Quezon Nueva Vizcaya. She has finished her studies in college but due to a lack of job opportunities, she volunteered to be a church worker in their simple village while running a sewing business at the same time.

Aside from her honorarium for being a church worker, she wanted to have a sideline to earn additional income. She is planning to be a retailer of gasoline in their Barangay (township) but she does not have sufficient capital. When she was informed about the programs and services of ASKI and Kiva loans, she felt encouraged to join and ask for additional capital to maintain her sewing business, still hoping that eventually, she would be able to start up her plan of gasoline retailing in their village.

Marilee is very happy to have her business because it is of great help to her family and makes her proud of herself for its success. She hopes to become even more successful someday and somehow to uplift her family’s poor living situation.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Aida

texts.en: Aida G., 43, almost lost all hope when one of her four kids met an accident that almost took his life. But faith and hard work pulls her through life’s trials. Her family lives in San Lazaro, Tala, Caloocan City. Her husband Rico works as a driver for a well-off family. Aida is into the hand-weaving of foot-rugs out of scrap fabric. She also makes home-made peanut butter and sells it to her neighbors. She earns a monthly net income of PHP 10,000 from these home-based businesses which she has been enjoying doing for the last ten years. Since joining the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in May 2005, Aida has been enjoying the many benefits for its members who are mostly housewives. Aida is now on her 9th loan with CCT. She is expecting to receive a fresh loan from the cooperative in the amount of PHP 14,000 which she will use to purchase scrap fabric from nearby garment factories as the chief material for her trendy foot-rugs. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her rug-making

loans.name: Cesar

texts.es:
César tiene 46 años, es padre dos preciosas niñas que están estudiando y vive con su esposa quien lo apoya en todo. Desde hace 4 años se dedica al transporte de pasajeros, anteriormente trabajaba vendiendo madera, pero debido a una operación al hígado, el médico le recomendó tener una vida muy activa. Por tal motivo, ser chofer de un motocarro es un trabajo adecuado para él y gracias a su esfuerzo diario, logró comprar su propio motocarro hace 2 años, en el cual viene trabajando. Lo que más le gusta a César de su actividad es relacionarse con muchas personas y conversar durante el recorrido, también le es muy rentable porque trabaja todo el día y como ya no tiene que pagar un alquiler del vehículo, todas sus ganancias son directamente para su familia.
Este es su primer préstamo con MFP, él se ha integrado a un banco comunal y lo que más le gusta de su grupo es que sus compañeros son personas responsables y muy generosas. Con el dinero que viene solicitando comprará repuestos para la reparación y mantenimiento de su motocarro.

loans.use: Compra de repuestos para su motocarro

loans.name: Samson Kibiwot

texts.en:
Samson is 49 years old and blessed with six children.His butchery is located in Chembulet centre and his major clients are residents who are staying within the centre.

He was introduced to KADET by a group member.

With the loan samson is expecting from KADET he intends to add more animals for slaughter .Also he itends to use part of it for paying school fees for his children.In the future he intends to buy a plot within the centre and build rental houses.


About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add more animals for slaughter.

loans.name: Ilyne

texts.en:
This loan is for Ilyne who is a direct seller of MSE, NATASHA, SUNDANCE, and AVON products (all of those products are cosmetics or apparel); her weekly net income is PHP 1,000. She has applied for a loan in the amount of PHP 6,000 for additional requirements and to purchase some personal collection to sell in their village again.

Ilyne hopes that KIVA lenders will approve her loan as soon as possible to finance her son's medication. Ilyne is a widow, a loving mother, whose child is Ryan Caine- 20 years of age, 3rd year college student. Unfortunately her son did not continue his education this first semester, because of asthma. He is under medication right now, and maybe next year he will be able to continue his education. She describes her village as quite productive; most of the people there are employed and busy.

loans.use: additional capital for her direct sales business

loans.name: Maria Fe

texts.en:
Maria Fe R., 52 years old, owns and manages a rice field. She has five children, all grown up and no longer living with them anymore. She likes growing rice because aside from the fact that she earns an income from selling her harvest, she enjoys working all day under the heat of the sun.

She is requesting a loan of Php 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to pay for farming necessities to grow her harvest. The loan is truly helpful in her pursuit of having an abundant harvest.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey S. is a villager in Trapeang S. village in Takeo province. She sells items such as grocery products, vegetables, food, and so on.

Since her business is doing well, Mrs. Srey S. wants to expand it by purchasing more goods to resell to earn more income.

Mrs. Srey S. has three children who are attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Khy Nhorn, is a soldier. He is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more goods to resell

loans.name: Mujeres Talentosas Group

texts.en: The Mujeres Talentosas committee is in its 10th loan cycle. The women in this group are incredibly hardworking. For example, Lourdes Peralta, who is 36 years old, has a young child who stays with her neighbor during the weekends so Lourdes can work. Lourdes sews baby clothes and sells them around her neighborhood. Her dream is to own her own home. She works very hard. She is the only breadwinner in her family. She lives in a small house in very poor conditions. The Fundacíon would like to renovate her house so that she can have a higher quality of living. Lourdes is part of this committee so that she can improve her life through her business.

loans.use: Merchandise

loans.name: Mazen

texts.en:
Mazen is a 28-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Mazen has been working as an electrician since 2004. His clients are his friends and neighbors. This is the first time that Mazen has requested a loan from the Kiva field partner, Al Majmoua.

He requested the loan to start and open a new business which will be selling mobile phones. This new business will allow him to increase his income. He plans to keep on working as an electrician, and to continue to improve his business.

loans.use: To start and open a new business

loans.name: Maria Eugenia

texts.es: La Sra. María Eugenia es una mujer de 33 años muy emprendedora, casada, tiene 3 hijos varones con 4,9 y 15 años de edad estudiantes el mayor es barbero. Su esposo trabaja como promotor y le ayuda con los gastos del hogar y la educación de sus hijos, ella actualmente cuenta con un pequeño cafetín, donde además de comida vende productos variados como accesorios para damas, está ubicado en el mercado oriental, hace trece años se dedica a vender en el negocio, lo inició con la ayuda de su esposo ya que el le dio la liquidación de su trabajo como contador para la compra de su tramo en el mercado y así decidió poner un cafetín en el cual ha venido trabajando poco a poco, hay momentos en que las ventas están bajas pero no deja de vender y siempre cuenta con la ayuda de su esposo, ambos sueñan con darles un mejor nivel de vida y educación a sus hijos, los planes que tiene para su negocio son poder algún día invertir en la infraestructura del mismo y comprar un termo grande para almacenar refrescos y gaseosas debido a la palta de energía eléctrica en algunas ocasiones. Ha solicitado un préstamo en AFODENIC, para la compra de gaseosas, golosinas y otras cosas que vende en su cafetín, se siente muy agradecida con la institución ya que ha hecho posible el financiamiento a los pequeños comerciantes.
texts.en:
María Eugenia is an enterprising 33 year-old woman who is married and has three school-aged sons who are 4,9, and 15 years old. The oldest of these works as a barber. Her husband works as a product promoter and helps her with the household and educational expenses for their children. She currently has a small cafe located in the eastern market. In addition to selling food in the cafe, she also sells accessories for women. She has had this business for 3 years; she started it with the help of her husband, who gave her the severance pay from his job as an accountant in order to pay for her place in the market. So, in this way she decided to start her cafe, which has been working little by little. There are times when the sales are low, but she does not stop selling and she always has the help of her husband. They both dream of giving their sons a better education and standard of life. They have plans to someday invest in the infrastructure of their business and also to buy a large cooler where they can store drinks and soft drinks, since at times the electricity goes down. They have requested a loan from AFODENIC to buy soft drinks, candy and other items to sell in the cafe. She feels very grateful to the institution, since it has made it possible to finance small businesses like hers.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, candy, and a variety of pastries

loans.name: Retamitas Group

texts.es: Rona C. A. integrante del grupo Retamitas por primera vez ingresará a ser parte de la familia de Pro Mujer  ya que necesita el préstamo para acceder a los servicios básicos como luz y agua, ella trabaja por la mañana en una carpintería, pintando y cepillando las maderas y muebles ya que tiene 3 hijos pequeños a los cuales no puede abandonar todo el día. Las demás integrantes del grupo Retamitas que se reúnen en el Centro Focal Santiago II tienen sus propios negocios que se dedican a la comercialización, servicio y producción.
texts.en:
Rona C. A. is a member of the "Retamitas" group. She will become part of the Pro Mujer family for the first time, since she needs a loan in order to gain access to basic necessities, such as power and water. She works in the mornings in a carpentry shop, painting and brushing the wood and furniture, since she has 3 small children whom she cannot abandon during the whole day. The other members of the "Retamitas" group who meet in the Santiago II Focal Center have their own businesses dedicated to commercialization, service and production.

Translated from Spanish by Tara Binetti, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Gloria María

texts.es:
En el mercado El Bisne de Chinandega, la señora Gloria H. se dedica a la actividad de venta de pan dulce y simple ofreciéndolo ambulantemente por las calles del mercado y llevando el productos en una pana la que pone en su cabeza y así va avanzando realizando la venta por todo el mercado.
Ella es madre de dos hijos a los que mantiene y busca la manera de brindarle las condiciones necesarias para su desarrollo. El crédito lo solicita para la compra del pan dulce para continuar ofreciéndolo y así mejorar las condiciones del negocio y por ende de su familia.
texts.en:
Gloria H. sells sweet and plain bread throughout Chinandega's El Bisne market. She wanders through the streets of the market with her product in a basket that she carries on her head. She has two children to support and seeks ways to provide them with the conditions necessary for their proper development. The funds will be used to buy sweet bread to continue selling it thus improving her business's condition and, thus, her family's as well.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bread.

loans.name: Laine

texts.en:
Laine H. is 47 and married with 10 children (ages 9 - 27).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Laine has many years of experience in this business.  Laine needs a loan of WST $1750 to rent land to raise additional crops.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2007, Laine joined SPBD.    This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Laine's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Laine H. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.5 out of 3
Level of Education:                         1.4 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:            1.5 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:                2.4 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to rent land to raise additional crops

loans.name: Mairamkul's Group

texts.ru:
Жизненные испытания, которые посылает судьба, постепенно закаляют человека и позволяют ему смотреть на жизнь с трезвым взглядом. Благодаря им, человек не ждёт подарков от судьбы, а сам начинает ковать своё счастье. Джумагулова  Майрамкул – лидер данной группы. Она вместе с семьёй проживает в г. Токмок. Майрамкул сорок шесть лет. Она вырастила троих детей и вполне выполнила свой родительский долг. Дети уже выросли. Две дочери уже замужем и живут отдельно. Сын Майрамкул пока ещё не работает. Что касается мужа, то он в данное время работает строителем. Последние годы Майрамкул работала в местной организации по производству национальных напитков и молочных продуктов, которое носит название “Максым”. Ровно год тому назад, Майрамкул начала думать о дополнительном источнике заработка. Тем более, график работы в “Максыме” позволял ей это. Она обратилась в “Мол Булак Финанс” за кредитом, и получив его начала торговать овощами на местном рынке. Чтобы начать торговлю Майрамкул понадобилось всего тысяча сомов. А теперь  от продажи овощей на рынке, она имеет полтора тысячи сомов ежемесячно. Майрамкул и на этот раз надеется, что сможет получить кредит. Она планирует увеличить ассортимент овощей для увеличения дохода, чтобы летом сделать ремонт дома. Подготовка к ремонту началась давно, и по этой причине, Майрамкул искренне верит, что у неё всё получится. 

У Майрамкул четыре партнёра по группе:

Исмаилову Нурбеку двадцать шесть лет. Он холост и работает охранником, в г. Токмок в ОсОО РАФА на фабрике по обработке шерсти. Из – за маленькой зарплаты, Нурбек уже на протяжении семи лет занимается перепродажей скота. Он надеется получить кредит и купить и закупить скот. 

Мадалиеву Рустаму тридцать один год. Он разведён, однако помогает жене и дочери. Рустам работает охранником на фабрике, и параллельно разводит цыплят. Он надеется получить кредит и закупить цыплят. 

Ивановой Ольге двадцать четыре года. Она замужем и имеет дочь. Чтобы помочь мужу прокормить семью, Ольга на дому начала шить платья и сдавать на продажу. Прибыль небольшая однако позволяет Ольге покрывать мелкие нужды. Ольге нужен кредит, чтобы купить курей.

Мадалиевой Мауджуде пятьдесят три года. Она разведена и является матерью двоих детей. Сын живёт отдельно, а дочь живёт вместе с Мауджудой. Мауджуда работает в киоске: продаёт газеты. Она надеется получить кредит, чтобы закупить товары для киоска.

--- WhereDidThisLoanComeFrom? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Life trials that fate sends us gradually strengthen a person and allow him to have a sober look at life. Thanks for these experiences, a person does not expect gifts from fate, but instead starts making his own happiness. Mairamkul D. is forty-six years old. She raised three children and fulfilled her parental obligation. The children are already grown. Two daughters are already married and live separately. Mairamkul’s son does not yet work. Her husband currently works as construction worker. Mairamkul spent the last few years working at a local national drinks and milk manufacturing company, called “Maksym.” Exactly one year ago, she started thinking about a supplemental source of income. Besides, her work schedule at “Maksym” allowed for it. She obtained a loan from “Mol Bulak Finance” and started selling vegetables at the local market. Mairamkul needed only one thousand som in order to start her retail business. And now she receives one and a half thousand som per month from the sales of vegetables. She hopes that she will obtain a loan this time. Mairamkul plans to expand the variety of vegetables in order to increase her income and repair her house in the summer. The preparations for the repairs started a long time ago, and this is why Mairamkul sincerely believes that everything will work out. Mairamkul has four partners in this group: Nurbek I. is twenty-six years old. He is single and works as a security guard at the yarn processing factory in Tokmak. Due to his low salary, Nurbek has been involved in livestock sales for seven years. He hopes to obtain a loan and buy livestock. Rustam M. is thirty-one years old. He is divorced, but helps his ex-wife and daughter. Rustam works as a security guard at a factory and also breeds chickens. He hopes to obtain a loan and buy chickens. Olga I. is twenty-four years old. She is married and has a daughter. To help her husband support the family, Olga began sewing dresses at home and selling them. The profit is small, but allows her to cover minor expenses. Olga needs a loan to buy chickens. Maudjuda M. is fifty-three years old. She is divorced and is a mother of two children. Her son lives separately, and the daughter lives with Maudjuda. Maudjuda works at a news stand and sells newspapers. She hopes to obtain a loan to purchase goods for her stand.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand the variety of vegetables in order to increase income and repair house

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph A. sells second hand clothes at Elmina. He is married and has three children. Joseph has a senior high education. His wife is a trader. He is responsible for paying school fees and utility bills. His loan will be used to buy more second hand clothing for sale. He hopes to use the new profits received as a result of the loan to save to buy land.

loans.use: To buy more second hand clothing to sell

loans.name: Creciendo En Fe 1,2 Group

texts.en:
Maria is the coordinator of her group, Creciendo en Fe. Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients, many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. Her group is located in the slums north of Santo Domingo, an area where crime is rampant and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their child.

Maria is excited to be taking her fourth loan with Esperanza, a Kiva partner, after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a pharmacy by purchasing medicines for colds, fever and diarrhea. She will use the profits to save toward her long-term goal of purchasing her own home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Medicines to supply her pharmacy

loans.name: Hout

texts.en:
Hout N., 48, is married and resides with his wife and four children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known for being the most populous city in Cambodia. He is a motor-taxi driver and security guard at a garment factory for an income of about USD 3 per day. His wife is a cleaner, earning an income of USD 2 per day to help cover the family expenses.  

N. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a new motorbike because his motorbike is old and consumes a lot of gasoline. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to support the children’s studies.  This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Cite Group

texts.fr:
CITE est un groupe de solidarité de 08 femmes toutes mariées exceptée Méta T. qui est veuve. Elles sont toutes du même village de NIAFOR dans la région de ZIGUINCHOR, elles sont d'âges très varié (entre 25 ans et 70 ans)

Elles mènent des activités diverses telles que le maraîchage, le commerce d'huile de palme et d'arachides

Le groupe, pour augmenter sa capacité d'autofinancement, a décidé d'adhérer à l'institution de micro-finance de CAURIE-MF en octobre 2002. Elles sont à leur 17ème crédit et n'ont jamais eu de problème de remboursement. 

Le crédit actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des intrants pour faire le maraîchage et pour s'approvisionner en quantité suffisante pour développer un commerce d'huile de palme et d'arachides.

Quant à la présidente du groupe de solidarité Madame Aramata G., elle est âgée de 46 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants en charge. Elle est vendeuse d'huile de palme et d'arachide et son objectif est de soutenir ses enfants sur le plan scolaire, santé et habillement.
texts.en:
CITE is a solidarity group of eight women who are all married, except for Méta T., who is a widow.  They are all from the same village of NIAFOR in the region of ZIGUINCHOR. Their ages are wide-ranging (from 25 to 70).  They operate diverse businesses, such as market gardening and commerce in palm oil and peanut oil.  To increase their ability to self-finance, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution CAURIE-MF in October 2002.  They are now on their 17th loan and have never had a problem repaying them.  The current loan will be used for buying some market gardening supplies and for stocking up sufficiently to develop a business in palm oil and peanut oil.  As for the solidarity group's president, Ms. Aramata G., she is 46 years old, married, and the mother of three children to support.  She is a seller of palm oil and peanut oil.  Her goal is to provide schooling, health care, and clothing to her children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: bolstering the solidarity group's ability to self-finance

loans.name: Ilhom

texts.en:
K. Ilhom is 50 years old. He is married with 3 children. For 20 years he has been running his beekeeping business. He started his business because he had difficulties finding employment. Family effort has been the key to his business's growth since everyone collaborates and now, he has a steady customer base due to the quality of his products. 

Currently, Ilhom is seeking a loan of $1500 USD that he wishes to spend on expanding his business, which will allow them to offer better services. Be a part of this family's achievements. They sincerely thank you for your support.   
   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Expanding his beekeeping business

loans.name: Andres Alexander

texts.es: El solicitante cuenta con buenas referencias, cuenta con un mototaxi es soltero vive en la casa de su hermana quien es su aval solidario. El destino del credito es para mantenimiento y reparacion de su movilidad
texts.en:
Andres is a motorcycle taxi driver who comes with good references. He is single and lives in the home of his sister, who is acting as his co-signer. This loan will be used to pay for maintenance and repairs to his vehicle.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for maintenance & repairs to his motorcycle taxi

loans.name: Naneth

texts.en:
Naneth P. is from the village of Valencia City. She is 36 years old. Naneth is married and has 3 infant children. To make a living, Naneth owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Naneth has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Naneth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Naneth is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Naneth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Arapathon's Group

texts.en: Arapathon J. is the leader of the group. She is 49 and married. She has raised two sons; both of them work in construction and earn 5,000 soms per month. Three years ago, Arapathon and her husband started to breed cattle. They started with the initial investment of 20,000 soms and now, by selling some animals after fattening, they make 5,000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for them to purchase a vehicle. With money received from the loan, Arapathon wants to purchase a calf for breeding and a dowry for her future daughter-in-law. In the future, she plans to increase the number of cattle and contribute some money to her son’s wedding. Gulmira T., 36, is married. Her husband works as a constructor in Russia. They have two daughters and two sons, all of whom study at school. In order to make money, Gulmira breeds cattle. She has been doing it for 21 years. By selling milk and some animals after fattening, Gulmira makes 5,000 soms per month. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase a calf for breeding. Mavzhuda A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 32 and married. Her husband works as a constructor in Russia. They have a son and a daughter; the son is a student and the daughter is not yet a student. Mavzhuda owns some land and she cultivates cotton. She has been doing it for 10 years, and by selling cotton, she makes 3,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Mavzhuda wants to purchase fertilizers for farming. Narinisa I., 45, is divorced. She has two sons; the older sons works in construction and the second son is a student. Four years ago, with the initial investment of 2,000 soms, Narinisa began to sew the national cloth and dressmaking supplies. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase fabrics and materials, and also to finish repairing the house. In the future, Narinisa wants to expand her business, finish repairing the house and contribute some money to her son’s wedding. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI (microfinance institution) in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: To purchase a calf for breeding

loans.name: Touch's Group

texts.en: This group in Tuol Sang Ka village, Takeo province consists of four members requesting a group loan. Mrs. Touch L. is the group leader and was born in 1967. She was selected by the other members, who will use portion of their loan for varied ways to support their businesses. She and her husband, Mr. Chrung Ly, are farmers who own a half-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell. Her husband is also a fisherman. Her problem is that her husband’s fishing supplies are too old to use. So to solve this problem, Mrs. Touch L. is asking for a loan to buy a fishing boat and fishing net to replace the old one. She is a mother of five children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the others attend local public school and help their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy a fishing boat and fishing net

loans.name: Kahramon

texts.en:
Committed first and foremost to his family, Kahramon works very hard at his ranching business. He has his own herd of cattle with which he works day after day to earn a living to support his dear wife and two children. 

Just as every business requires investment, Kahramon's business now needs to add some young bulls, which will be raised and sold. For this reason, he once again has turned to IMON International to obtain a loan to acquire the cattle and, in this way, serve to help improve the standard of living of his beloved family.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase of young cattle

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia P. is from the village of Maligaya, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 42 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Sylvia owns and operates a furniture-making business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making and selling cabinets and wardrobe furniture to local businesses and community members. Sylvia has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Sylvia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. As with her previous loan from ASKI which has been repaid, Sylvia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will also be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This will be the third loan that Sylvia has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make furniture

loans.name: Mario Jose

texts.es:
Mario es un hombre trabajador, pequeño comerciante que ha logrado crecer gracias a los financiamientos que Afodenic ha otorgado.
Su negocio es la venta de cd y películas el cual lleva once años en las ventas el cual tiene un local pequeño pero también vende ambulante para lograr vender ya que las ventas se  ponen bajas y tiene que buscar la forma de recorrer dinero para lograr cubrir los gastos.
Su casa la ha venido mejorando también con los financiamiento ha logrado hacer un bajarete, repello a las paredes, compro puertas nuevas. Hoy con este préstamo hará un cuarto en donde comprara materiales de construcción como: piedra, arena, bloques, cemento hierro, láminas de zinc, perlines y comenzar hacer su cuarto logrando mejor espacio para su familia.
texts.en:
Mario is a working man. He is a small businessman who has been able to grow thanks to the loans AFODENIC has offered to him. His business of the last 11 years is selling CDs and movies. He has a small storefront but he also sells on foot because his sales have been dropping, so he has to look for a way to make enough money to cover expenses. He has also been using the loans to make improvements to his house. He has built a small covered patio, reinforced the walls, and bought new doors. Now, with this loan, he will build another room. He will buy construction materials like rock, sand, cinder blocks, cement, iron bars, corrugated metal sheets, and roof beams, and he will start to build a room to give his family a better living space.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to make his family more comfortable by buying construction materials like rock, sand, cement, iron bars, corrugated metal sheets, etc., and building another room towards the back of his house

loans.name: Hoeun

texts.en:
Hoeun L., 31, lives with her husband, Sok-eng Rin, 34, in a small village along the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They were married in 2002 and have two young children: a son and a daughter. Hoeun and her husband are in the photo above.  

Hoeun has been working as a cleaner for a year now. In the past, she used to be a silk weaver. Her husband is an auto repairman. Hoeun is applying for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a new motorbike for commuting. Her motorbike broke down often, was costly to repair, and consumed more gasoline than newer motorbikes. Hence Hoeun has decided to sell it and wants to purchase a new motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle for commuting

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia A. is from the village of San Andres, Kadingilan, Bukidnon. She is 39 years old. Amalia is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Amalia owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Amalia has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5000 PHP per month for these activities.

In 2010, Amalia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Amalia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell in her shop.
